# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is the solution in Julia using DataFrames.jl package:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df[((df[:manufacturer] .== "audi") .& ((df[:model] .== "a4") .| (df[:model] .== "a4 quattro"))), :audi_a4_type] = true;
    return df
end
```
This function takes a DataFrame as input. It first filters rows where manufacturer is 'audi' and model is either 'a4' or 'a4 quattro'. Then it creates a new column named 'audi_a4_type' in the filtered rows and set its value to `true`. The modified DataFrame is then returned by the function.

You can call this function with your dataframe:
```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"], model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)
```
This will return a dataframe with the 'audi_a4_type' column set to `true` for rows where manufacturer is 'audi' and model is either 'a4' or 'a4 quattro'. The rest of the columns remain unchanged.
